data.title: Piping STDIN into Atom CLI
data.body:
When trying out Atom 1.0, I was totally digging it until I went to the command line and tried:

```
ls | atom
```

And I got a blank document.  After some searching I found this [discussion thread](https://discuss.atom.io/t/it-would-be-nice-to-be-able-to-pipe-standard-out-to-atom-and-have-it-open-in-an-unsaved-document/4781).  Seems that a lot of folks would like this and for me, it is part of my daily workflow.

I searched the issues and pull requests here and couldn't find an issue for this, but please close if this topic has already come and gone.

Cheers and thanks!

data.title: Window position not remembered after Reload
data.body:
Atom 1.0, Mac OS 10.10.

Steps to reproduce:
- Launch Atom
- Move the Atom window to a secondary monitor and resize the Atom window
- Go to View > Reload
- (BUG) When Atom is reloaded it's moved back to it's original position and size

Expected behaviour:
- Atom should remember where the user can moved the window and what size it was between reloads

This is not an issue on Windows (where the window reloads in the correct location). Not sure if this is Atom-specific or an issue with Electron.

data.title: Unable to remap "cmd+d" keys
data.body:
Mac OS, Atom 1.0

I'd like "cmd+d" to duplicate the currently line. This is more natural to me than the default "cmd+shift+d" command.

I went into "Atom > Open Your Keymap" and set it to:

```
'.atom-text-editor':
   'cmd-d': 'editor:duplicate-lines'
```

However, this seems to have no effect. cmd+d still selects the previous character instead of duplicating the line.

Based on everything I've seen in the docs - this should work. Any ideas what I'm doing wrong?

data.title: Encode UTF-8
data.body:
There are a problem with UTF-8 encoding.

I've opened a .HTM file (UTF-8) and save some changes.

Then the word "ações" has become " aï¿½ï¿½es"

I've tried several times, the ATOM is set to UTF-8.

data.title: Problems overriding alt-up + alt-down in keymap.cson
data.body:
I'm trying to override alt-up + alt-down to move a line up/down.  Using the Settings helper, I copied the bindings as a template and then added the following to my keymap.cson file:

```
'atom-workspace atom-text-editor':
  'alt-up': 'editor:move-line-up'

'atom-workspace atom-text-editor':
  'alt-down': 'editor:move-line-down'
```

I can now use alt-down to move a line down, but the binding for alt-up isn't getting picked up.  If I swap the order of them, so that the line-down block is before the line-up block, then line-up works but line-down does not.

Any ideas on what I'm doing wrong?

data.title: No menu bar at all with global menus on Linux
data.body:
Using Arch Linux, KDE 4 with DBusMenu and Atom 1.0.0.  I can’t see a menu bar, I also can’t enable it in any way, and it does not appear on my panel either.  It worked in 0.211.0.

```
local/libdbusmenu 12.10.2-2
    A library for passing menus over DBus
local/libdbusmenu-glib 12.10.2-4
    A library for passing menus over DBus
local/libdbusmenu-gtk2 12.10.2-3
    A library for passing menus over DBus
local/libdbusmenu-gtk3 12.10.2-4
    A library for passing menus over DBus
local/libdbusmenu-qt4 0.9.3+15.10.20150604-1
    A library that provides a Qt4 implementation of the DBusMenu spec
local/libdbusmenu-qt5 0.9.3+15.10.20150604-1
    A library that provides a Qt implementation of the DBusMenu spec
local/atom-editor-bin 1.0.0-1
    Chrome-based text editor from Github - Precompiled binary from official repository
```

data.title: A deprecation warning is still displayed to the user on the package settings page
data.body: > Deprecated APIs will be removed when Atom 1.0 is released in June. Please update your packages.

data.title: can i set auto-detect encoding as default
data.body: it always opens as utf8 ,  can i set auto-detect as default ？

data.title: Ctrl+<arrow> move of line should update its indentation
data.body:
Being able to move a line with Ctrl+arrow is very useful.

I suggest this feature be improved so the line matches the indentation in its new scope, e.g. being "unindented" if moving out of a FOR loop.

data.title: Markdown highlight corrupts after *>
data.body:
While editing a .md file, the highlight behaves incorrectly after *> occured in text. The whole file is displayed in pink after that. Please see the screenshot. 
v 1.0.0 .deb package (it was also present in 0.188)
![screenshot from 2015-06-29 14 26 58](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5337921/8406992/edf2aa1e-1e6a-11e5-9bbd-7150a1b700b0.png)

data.body:

file charset is utf-8  .

when i open the file with atom,  I just don't show correct ..  

try type this word:

```

```

data.title: launching atom from bash no-longer opens current pwd (Os X)
data.body:
Prior to 1.0, running 'atom' from a bash terminal in a project directory would load the editor, and open the 'tree view' to the present working directory.

Since updating to 1.0.0 this behaviour has ceased.

May be i can do this in default but where?

data.title: Keymap with or without dot notation?
data.body:
I'm not sure but I guess since Atom 1.0 the keymap seems to use classes without dots.

Here is the example from the keymap.cson:

```
# Here's an example taken from Atom's built-in keymap:
#
# '.atom-text-editor':
#   'enter': 'editor:newline'
#
# 'body':
#   'ctrl-P': 'core:move-up'
#   'ctrl-p': 'core:move-down'
```

So according to this, I would make a override of any keymapping like this, **which isn't working**

```
'.atom-workspace .atom-text-editor:not([mini])':
  'cmd-k cmd-d': 'editor:fold-all'
```

To make it work, I remove the dots from the classes

```
'atom-workspace atom-text-editor:not([mini])':
  'cmd-k cmd-d': 'editor:fold-all'
```

So it looks like the examples provided in the file comments are outdated or this is a bug, I don't know.

data.title: Altgr (ctrl-alt) doesn’t work correctly on Linux
data.body: I’m using a [bépo](http://bepo.fr/wiki/Accueil) keyboard layout. On Windows, when hitting _AltGr_, I get it translated to `ctrl-alt`. On Linux, I get it translated to… `á`, which is very weird and wrong.

data.title: Installing Atom on Mageia 5
data.body:
Hi, 

I know that instructions for installing Atom on 32 bit Mageia 5 do not exist in [Linux.md](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/docs/build-instructions/linux.md) which is why I thought I'd try to create them by figuring out how to install it myself. Nodejs installation instructions are not included at the Wiki site linked for Mageia or any Mandriva-based distribution, so I decided to install it from source. I made it up to the final stage of Atom installation and through Nodejs installation without error. Namely I made it to `sudo script/grunt install` without issue, the problem is that at the `sudo script/grunt install` stage I received errors stating that `/usr/bin/env` was a bad interpreter. So I deleted it using `sudo rm /usr/bin/env` and created a virtual link between nodejs and env in /usr/bin, namely by running `sudo ln -s /usr/bin/nodejs /usr/bin/env` but it made no difference. How do I rectify this problem? 

Thanks for your time,
Brenton

data.title: Possible to accept commands/key bindings without Atom window?
data.body:
For example when using the [Atom project manager](https://github.com/danielbrodin/atom-project-manager), it's very inconvenient that when you've closed all your windows and want to open a new project, you have to open a new Atom window first before the command to open a new project can be used.

Seeing how this command is more of a "global" command, and shouldn't really need a window, is it possible for Atom to somehow accept such commands without window (but with the app itself having focus) and just open a new window as needed?

The work around now is to either remember not to close your last project window, open a new project, and then switch back to close the last one, or close all of them, open a new window, and then open a new project. Since opening a new window takes quite a bit of time to load, it's a bit of a hassle whichever way you do it, and it would be much more optimal if you could just open an existing project, and for that command to open the new window for you.

data.title: Cursor offset right from Unicode content
data.body:
Hi,

I'm editing some files which include Myanmar text. This includes diacritic characters (meaning char + char adding a diacritic (above / below / left / right) the previous char). Atom appears to give each char equal space, meaning that I need to click right of the text to select it, and the highlight appears offset right, too. Each string makes it more difficult to highlight text appearing after it on the line.

![screen shot 2015-06-29 at 3 16 43 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/643918/8402027/e85fe6c8-1e71-11e5-92db-2fa52ebd3203.png)

Put the text နေပြည်တော် in the middle of a long line to see what this looks like. This problem will occur with many other scripts, for example Devanagari used widely in India and Nepal - use this text: देवनागरी. Can you use HTML5 Canvas measureText() ?

data.title: [UX] Settings pane checkbox not bound to labels (but act as if)
data.body:
Hovering labels in the settings pane results in a pointer cursor. Holding down the cursor results in the checkbox lighting up.

Yet, unless clicking directly on the checkbox, it will not be checked upon clicking.

Clicking the labels should toggle the checkbox. Especially considering the existing hover and mousedown behaviour 

> Version 1.0.0 (1.0.0)
> Mac OS X 10.10.3

data.title: Cannot drag inactive tabs without focusing them first.
data.body:
You have to make a tab/pane active first, before you are able to click-drag it, to reorder, or move across to another pane.
#### Steps to reproduce:
1. Open up a file in Atom.
2. Split the panes in whichever way you want.
3. Click on either pane/tab to make it active/bring it to focus.
4. Try click-dragging the other file into the opposite pane.

data.title: [Feature request]: Windows taskbar/system tray icon.
data.body: Simple concept, make it so users have the option to minimize to system tray on close and add a system tray icon for reopening Atom.
